chapterSummaries.54: Davidic (when Ziphites betrayed him). Theme: prayer for deliverance. David trusts God to repay his enemies and uphold him.
chapterSummaries.55: Davidic. Theme: betrayal’s pain. David laments treachery by a close companion but casts his burden on the Lord.
chapterSummaries.56: Davidic (when seized by Philistines in Gath). Theme: trust amid fear. When afraid, David trusts God, who delivers him from death.
chapterSummaries.57: Davidic (when fleeing Saul in a cave). Theme: refuge in God. Amid danger, David sings praise for God’s steadfast love and faithfulness.
chapterSummaries.58: Davidic. Theme: condemnation of unjust rulers. The wicked are likened to venomous snakes, but the righteous rejoice at God’s judgment.
chapterSummaries.59: Davidic (when Saul sent men to watch his house). Theme: deliverance from enemies. David prays for protection and praises God as fortress.
chapterSummaries.60: Davidic (after battle with Aram and Edom). Theme: national lament and hope. Israel cries for restoration, but God promises victory.
chapterSummaries.61: Davidic. Theme: prayer for refuge. From the ends of the earth David cries to God, asking to be led to the rock higher than himself and to dwell in God’s presence forever.
chapterSummaries.62: Davidic. Theme: trust in God alone. Salvation, honor, and refuge are found in God, not in wealth or human strength.
chapterSummaries.63: Davidic (when in the wilderness of Judah). Theme: longing for God’s presence. David thirsts for God, praising Him even in dry and weary places.
chapterSummaries.64: Davidic. Theme: deliverance from secret plots. David laments the schemes of the wicked, but God will strike them down.
chapterSummaries.65: Davidic (song of praise). Theme: God’s abundant provision. The psalm celebrates God’s forgiveness, power over creation, and blessing of the earth.
chapterSummaries.66: Anonymous (hymn). Theme: praise for God’s mighty deeds. The psalmist recalls God’s works in Israel’s history and personal deliverance.
chapterSummaries.67: Anonymous (song). Theme: God’s blessing for the nations. A prayer that God’s face shine on His people so all nations may know His salvation.
chapterSummaries.68: Davidic. Theme: God as victorious warrior. God scatters His enemies, cares for the fatherless, and dwells in Zion amid triumph.
chapterSummaries.69: Davidic (lament/messianic). Theme: suffering servant. David cries out in deep distress, foreshadowing Christ’s passion.
chapterSummaries.70: Davidic. Theme: urgent plea for help. A short psalm asking God to deliver quickly from adversaries.
chapterSummaries.71: Anonymous (likely elderly psalmist). Theme: lifelong trust. From youth to old age, the psalmist declares God’s faithfulness and seeks continued deliverance.
chapterSummaries.72: Solomonic (or for Solomon). Theme: the ideal king. A prayer for righteous rule, justice for the poor, and worldwide dominion; foreshadows Christ.
chapterSummaries.73: Asaph (wisdom psalm). Theme: struggle with the prosperity of the wicked. The psalmist finds resolution in God’s presence and eternal justice.
chapterSummaries.74: Asaph. Theme: lament over destruction. The psalmist cries to God after the sanctuary is defiled, pleading for deliverance from enemies.
chapterSummaries.75: Asaph. Theme: God the righteous judge. The psalm declares that exaltation comes from God, who will bring down the wicked.
chapterSummaries.76: Asaph. Theme: God’s awe-inspiring power. God is praised for His victory over enemies, instilling fear among the nations.
chapterSummaries.77: Asaph. Theme: remembering God’s deeds. In trouble, the psalmist recalls God’s wonders, especially the exodus, as grounds for hope.
chapterSummaries.78: Asaph (historical psalm). Theme: Israel’s repeated rebellion. The psalm recounts God’s faithfulness and Israel’s failures, urging future generations to trust Him.
chapterSummaries.79: Asaph (communal lament). Theme: plea after destruction. The psalmist cries out as Jerusalem lies in ruins, asking God for mercy and justice.
chapterSummaries.80: Asaph. Theme: prayer for restoration. God is addressed as the Shepherd of Israel, asked to shine His face and save His people.
chapterSummaries.81: Asaph. Theme: call to covenant faithfulness. God recalls His deliverance of Israel, urges obedience, and laments their stubbornness.
chapterSummaries.82: Asaph. Theme: God the supreme Judge. God rebukes unjust earthly rulers, declaring His authority over all nations.
chapterSummaries.83: Asaph. Theme: prayer against hostile nations. The psalmist pleads with God to defeat conspiring enemies and show His supremacy.
chapterSummaries.84: Sons of Korah. Theme: longing for God’s dwelling. Blessed are those who live in God’s house and find strength in His presence.
chapterSummaries.85: Sons of Korah. Theme: plea for restoration. The psalm recalls past deliverance, prays for revival, and trusts in God’s steadfast love.
chapterSummaries.86: Davidic. Theme: prayer for mercy and help. David cries out for God’s grace and affirms His greatness among the nations.
chapterSummaries.87: Sons of Korah. Theme: Zion, the city of God. Nations are counted as born in Zion, showing God’s universal plan of redemption.
chapterSummaries.88: Sons of Korah (Heman the Ezrahite). Theme: darkest lament. The psalmist cries out from deep suffering, feeling abandoned by God.
chapterSummaries.89: Ethan the Ezrahite. Theme: God’s covenant with David. The psalm praises God’s faithfulness but laments apparent rejection of the king.
chapterSummaries.90: Moses. Theme: God’s eternity and human frailty. Life is short under God’s wrath, so the psalmist asks God to teach us to number our days.
chapterSummaries.91: Anonymous. Theme: God our refuge. Those who dwell in His shelter are protected; He delivers from fear, plague, and danger.
chapterSummaries.92: Anonymous (Sabbath psalm). Theme: praise for God’s works. The righteous flourish like palm trees while the wicked perish.
chapterSummaries.93: Anonymous. Theme: God reigns in majesty. The Lord is enthroned, mightier than the seas, and His decrees stand firm.
chapterSummaries.94: Anonymous. Theme: plea for justice. The psalmist asks God to punish the arrogant and affirms His discipline brings blessing.
chapterSummaries.95: Anonymous. Theme: call to worship and obedience. God is the great King; Israel is warned not to harden their hearts like in the wilderness.
chapterSummaries.96: Anonymous. Theme: God’s reign proclaimed to the nations. A new song celebrates His glory and coming judgment with equity.
chapterSummaries.97: Anonymous. Theme: the Lord reigns. Fire and lightning reveal His glory, idols are shamed, and the righteous rejoice in Him.
chapterSummaries.98: Anonymous. Theme: joy in God’s salvation. Sing to the Lord for His marvelous deeds; He will judge the world with righteousness.
chapterSummaries.99: Anonymous. Theme: the holy King. God reigns over nations in justice, exalted in Zion, worthy of worship.
chapterSummaries.100: Anonymous (thanksgiving psalm). Theme: call to joyful worship. All lands are summoned to serve the Lord with gladness, for His steadfast love endures forever.
chapterSummaries.101: Davidic. Theme: commitment to integrity. David vows to live blamelessly, reject wickedness, and rule justly in his house.
chapterSummaries.102: Anonymous (penitential/lament). Theme: prayer of the afflicted. The psalmist laments personal and national suffering, yet affirms God’s eternal reign and future restoration of Zion.
chapterSummaries.103: Davidic. Theme: praise for God’s mercy. Bless the Lord, who forgives, heals, redeems, and shows steadfast love from everlasting to everlasting.
chapterSummaries.104: Anonymous (hymn). Theme: God the Creator and Sustainer. The psalm celebrates God’s majesty, creation’s order, and His providential care for all creatures.
chapterSummaries.105: Anonymous (historical psalm). Theme: God’s covenant faithfulness. Recounts God’s deeds from Abraham through the exodus and settlement in Canaan.
chapterSummaries.106: Anonymous. Theme: Israel’s unfaithfulness. The psalm confesses sins throughout Israel’s history, yet affirms God’s steadfast love and plea for deliverance.
chapterSummaries.107: Anonymous. Theme: thanksgiving for deliverance. God rescues people from distress—wanderers, prisoners, the sick, and sailors—showing His steadfast love.
chapterSummaries.108: Davidic (combination of Psalms 57 & 60). Theme: confidence in victory. David praises God and calls for His help over nations.
chapterSummaries.109: Davidic (lament). Theme: plea against false accusers. David calls for judgment on his enemies but ends affirming God as his deliverer.
chapterSummaries.110: Davidic (royal/messianic psalm). Theme: the Lord’s anointed king and priest. The Messiah reigns at God’s right hand as priest forever.
chapterSummaries.111: Anonymous. Theme: praise for God’s works. His deeds are majestic, His covenant remembered, and His precepts trustworthy.
chapterSummaries.112: Anonymous (wisdom psalm). Theme: blessings of the righteous. Those who fear the Lord are steadfast, generous, and remembered forever.
chapterSummaries.113: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: praise to the exalted Lord. God raises the poor and needy, showing His greatness.
chapterSummaries.114: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: God’s power at the exodus. The sea fled and mountains trembled at His presence.
chapterSummaries.115: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: God vs. idols. Unlike powerless idols, the Lord blesses those who trust Him.
chapterSummaries.116: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: thanksgiving for deliverance. The psalmist loves the Lord who heard his cry and vows to call on Him forever.
chapterSummaries.117: Anonymous (shortest psalm). Theme: universal praise. All nations are called to glorify God for His steadfast love.
chapterSummaries.118: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: thanksgiving for God’s salvation. The rejected stone becomes the cornerstone; His love endures forever.
chapterSummaries.119: Anonymous (acrostic psalm). Theme: delight in God’s law. The longest psalm exalts God’s word as life-giving, guiding, and sustaining.
chapterSummaries.120: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: prayer for deliverance. The psalmist, living among deceitful people, calls on the Lord for peace.
chapterSummaries.121: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: God our keeper. The psalmist lifts eyes to the hills, affirming help comes from the Lord, who guards His people day and night.
chapterSummaries.122: Davidic (Song of Ascents). Theme: joy in Jerusalem. The psalmist rejoices in going to God’s house and prays for the peace of Jerusalem.
chapterSummaries.123: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: plea for mercy. The psalmist looks to God’s hand like a servant to a master, asking for mercy amid scorn.
chapterSummaries.124: Davidic (Song of Ascents). Theme: God our deliverer. If the Lord had not been on Israel’s side, enemies would have swallowed them alive.
chapterSummaries.125: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: security in God. Those who trust the Lord are like Mount Zion, unshakable and enduring forever.
chapterSummaries.126: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: restoration joy. The psalm recalls God’s past restoration and prays for renewed blessing, with weeping turning into joy.
chapterSummaries.127: Solomonic (Song of Ascents). Theme: God builds and sustains. Labor, security, and family prosper only by God’s blessing.
chapterSummaries.128: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: blessings of fearing God. Those who walk in His ways enjoy fruitful family life and peace in Israel.
chapterSummaries.129: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: perseverance amid affliction. Though afflicted from youth, Israel affirms the Lord’s justice against oppressors.
chapterSummaries.130: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: hope in forgiveness. From the depths, the psalmist cries for mercy, waiting on God’s steadfast love and redemption.
chapterSummaries.131: Davidic (Song of Ascents). Theme: humility and trust. David quiets his soul like a weaned child, resting in the Lord.
chapterSummaries.132: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: God’s covenant with David. The psalm recalls David’s devotion and affirms God’s promise to dwell in Zion.
chapterSummaries.133: Davidic (Song of Ascents). Theme: blessing of unity. Brothers dwelling in unity is like precious oil and the dew of Hermon.
chapterSummaries.134: Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: call to bless the Lord. Servants of the Lord in His house are exhorted to lift hands in praise.
chapterSummaries.135: Anonymous (hymn). Theme: praise for God’s mighty acts. Unlike idols, God does whatever He pleases and vindicates His people.
chapterSummaries.136: Anonymous (liturgical psalm). Theme: God’s steadfast love endures forever. Recounts creation, exodus, conquest, and ongoing providence with refrain.
chapterSummaries.137: Anonymous (exilic lament). Theme: grief in Babylon. Exiles weep by the rivers, remembering Zion, and call for justice on their captors.
chapterSummaries.138: Davidic. Theme: thanksgiving for God’s steadfast love. David praises God’s faithfulness and prays for continued care.
chapterSummaries.139: Davidic. Theme: God’s intimate knowledge. God knows all thoughts and deeds, is present everywhere, and formed us in the womb.
chapterSummaries.140: Davidic. Theme: prayer for deliverance from the violent. David asks God to protect him from evildoers and affirms His justice for the needy.
chapterSummaries.141: Davidic. Theme: prayer for purity and protection. David asks God to guard his words and heart, and to keep him safe from the wicked.
chapterSummaries.142: Davidic (when in the cave). Theme: cry from isolation. David pours out his complaint, acknowledging God as his only refuge.
chapterSummaries.143: Davidic (penitential psalm). Theme: prayer for mercy and guidance. David confesses human unrighteousness and seeks God’s deliverance and leading.
chapterSummaries.144: Davidic. Theme: God who gives victory. David praises God as his rock, prays for deliverance, and asks blessing on the nation.
chapterSummaries.145: Davidic (acrostic hymn). Theme: praise of God’s greatness. The psalmist exalts God’s majesty, goodness, and everlasting kingdom.
chapterSummaries.146: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: trust in God, not princes. God cares for the oppressed, blind, and stranger; He reigns forever.
chapterSummaries.147: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: praise for God’s care. God heals the brokenhearted, governs creation, and blesses Jerusalem.
chapterSummaries.148: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: all creation praises God. Heaven, earth, animals, and people are summoned to worship the Lord.
chapterSummaries.149: Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: call to joyful praise. God’s people rejoice in Him and triumph over enemies with His justice.
chapterSummaries.150: Anonymous (final Hallel psalm). Theme: universal praise. In a climactic call, everything that has breath is exhorted to praise the Lord with instruments and song.

chapterSummaries.1: Proverbs begins with a call to wisdom, warning against enticement of sinners and urging fear of the Lord as the foundation of knowledge.
chapterSummaries.2: Wisdom protects from evil, delivering from wicked men and adulterous women, and grants understanding of righteousness and justice.
chapterSummaries.3: Trust in the Lord with all your heart. Wisdom brings blessing, healing, and favor. Discipline and generosity are encouraged.
chapterSummaries.4: A father instructs his son to pursue wisdom diligently, avoiding the path of the wicked and walking in righteousness.
chapterSummaries.5: Warnings against adultery: the seductress leads to destruction. Faithfulness in marriage is commended.
chapterSummaries.6: Warnings against laziness, dishonesty, and sowing discord. Adultery is again condemned as self-destructive.
chapterSummaries.7: A vivid warning against the adulteress, showing how she entices and destroys the foolish young man.
chapterSummaries.8: Wisdom personified calls out, declaring her role in creation and her blessings for those who seek her.
chapterSummaries.9: Wisdom and folly are personified as hostesses inviting guests. Choosing wisdom leads to life; folly leads to death.
chapterSummaries.10: Proverbs of Solomon begin, contrasting the righteous and the wicked in speech, work, and destiny.
chapterSummaries.11: Righteousness brings life and stability, while wickedness leads to downfall. Generosity is rewarded.
chapterSummaries.12: The righteous are established, diligent, and truthful; the wicked face trouble and ruin.
chapterSummaries.13: Wise living brings blessing; laziness, folly, and poor speech lead to ruin.
chapterSummaries.14: The wise build up, but the foolish tear down. Righteousness exalts a nation; sin is a reproach.
chapterSummaries.15: Gentle words turn away wrath. God sees all. Righteousness and humility bring blessing.
chapterSummaries.16: Commit your works to the Lord. God directs human steps. Pride leads to downfall; humility to honor.
chapterSummaries.17: Better peace with little than strife with plenty. The Lord tests hearts. Friends love; fools bring grief.
chapterSummaries.18: Words bring life or death. A fool loves quarrels. A brother offended is hard to win back.
chapterSummaries.19: Wealth attracts many friends. Discipline children. Fear of the Lord leads to life.
chapterSummaries.20: Honesty is valued. Wine leads to mockery. The Lord directs steps. A faithful person is rare.
chapterSummaries.21: God weighs hearts. Sacrifice is meaningless without obedience. Righteousness brings life.
chapterSummaries.22: A good name is better than riches. Train up a child in the way he should go. Warnings against debt and injustice.
chapterSummaries.23: Warnings against gluttony, drunkenness, and envy. Parents are urged to discipline children in wisdom.
chapterSummaries.24: Do not envy evildoers. Wisdom builds houses. The righteous may fall but rise again. Prepare for battle with counsel.
chapterSummaries.25: Proverbs of Solomon copied by Hezekiah’s men. Wise speech, patience, and self-control are praised.
chapterSummaries.26: Fools despise wisdom. Laziness and gossip cause ruin. Hypocrisy and deceit are condemned.
chapterSummaries.27: Do not boast about tomorrow. Iron sharpens iron. Faithful friends are a blessing.
chapterSummaries.28: The wicked flee though none pursue. Greed and injustice bring ruin. Trust in the Lord brings prosperity.
chapterSummaries.29: A stiff-necked people are destroyed. Discipline brings wisdom. Righteousness exalts a nation.
chapterSummaries.30: Sayings of Agur: reflections on human limits, creation’s wonders, and warnings against arrogance.
chapterSummaries.31: Sayings of King Lemuel: warnings against lust and drunkenness. The virtuous woman is praised for her wisdom, diligence, and fear of the Lord.

chapterSummaries.1: The Teacher reflects on life’s futility: all is vanity. Generations come and go, and nothing is truly new under the sun.
chapterSummaries.2: The Teacher pursues pleasure, projects, wealth, and wisdom, yet finds them meaningless. Both wise and foolish share the same fate of death.
chapterSummaries.3: There is a time for everything under heaven. God has made everything beautiful in its time. Humans cannot fathom His work from beginning to end.
chapterSummaries.4: The Teacher laments oppression, envy, and toil. Companionship is better than isolation, for two are stronger than one.
chapterSummaries.5: Caution is urged in approaching God. Wealth and possessions cannot satisfy, but fearing God and enjoying His gifts brings meaning.
chapterSummaries.6: Riches without the ability to enjoy them are meaningless. Human desires are endless, and the future is uncertain.
chapterSummaries.7: Wisdom is valuable, though limited. The Teacher reflects on human wickedness and the importance of fearing God.
chapterSummaries.8: Obedience to kings is urged, but ultimate sovereignty belongs to God. Humans cannot fully understand His ways.
chapterSummaries.9: Death comes to all. The Teacher urges enjoying life’s simple pleasures as God’s gift, for wisdom and effort alone cannot control outcomes.
chapterSummaries.10: Wisdom protects, but folly brings danger. Leaders and workers are exhorted to act wisely and avoid foolishness.
chapterSummaries.11: Take risks and be generous, for the future is uncertain. Youth should rejoice but remember God will judge all deeds.
chapterSummaries.12: Remember your Creator in youth, before old age and death come. The conclusion: fear God and keep His commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.

chapterSummaries.1: The bride expresses her love and desire for her beloved. She delights in his affection, and he praises her beauty.
chapterSummaries.2: The bride and groom delight in each other. The bride longs for her beloved’s presence. Love is described as delightful and life-giving.
chapterSummaries.3: The bride searches for her beloved at night and finds him. A royal wedding procession is described with splendor.
chapterSummaries.4: The groom praises the bride’s beauty in detail. Their love is celebrated as a garden of delight.
chapterSummaries.5: The bride dreams of her beloved, but he withdraws when she hesitates. She searches for him, suffering mistreatment, and describes his excellence.
chapterSummaries.6: The bride praises her beloved. The groom describes her beauty and uniqueness, exalting her above others.
chapterSummaries.7: The groom praises the bride’s physical beauty with imagery of grace and fruitfulness. Their mutual desire and intimacy are expressed.
chapterSummaries.8: The bride desires public acknowledgment of their love. Love is celebrated as strong and unyielding. The poem concludes with longing and union.

chapterSummaries.1: God calls out Israel's rebellion and sin, comparing the nation to Sodom and Gomorrah. Despite their religious rituals, God rejects their worship because of injustice and oppression. He calls for repentance and promises restoration if they obey.
chapterSummaries.2: Isaiah's vision of the future temple mountain where all nations will come to learn God's ways. Swords will be beaten into plowshares in the messianic age. The prophet calls people to walk in God's light rather than in pride and idolatry.
chapterSummaries.3: God's judgment on Jerusalem and Judah for their corrupt leadership and social injustice. The proud women of Zion will be humbled. Leaders who should guide the people instead lead them astray, bringing divine judgment.
chapterSummaries.4: After judgment comes purification and restoration. The Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and glorious. Jerusalem will be cleansed, and God's presence will return as a canopy of protection over Mount Zion.
chapterSummaries.5: The song of the vineyard - God planted Israel as a vineyard expecting justice but found bloodshed, righteousness but cries of distress. Six woes are pronounced on the wicked. God will bring foreign nations to judge Israel.
chapterSummaries.6: Isaiah's call vision in the year King Uzziah died. He sees the Lord on His throne, seraphim proclaiming God's holiness. Isaiah confesses his sinfulness, is cleansed, and accepts God's commission to preach to a hardened people.
chapterSummaries.7: The Immanuel prophecy during Ahaz's reign. Syria and Israel threaten Judah, but God promises deliverance through a virgin bearing a son called Immanuel. Ahaz's lack of faith brings Assyrian invasion.
chapterSummaries.8: The birth of Maher-shalal-hash-baz as a sign of coming judgment. Isaiah's disciples are sealed as witnesses. The chapter warns against seeking mediums instead of God's word, ending with hope for those in darkness.
chapterSummaries.9: The great light shining in darkness - a child is born who will be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace. His government will bring endless peace to David's throne. God's anger burns against Israel's pride.
chapterSummaries.10: Woe to those who make unjust laws and deprive the poor of justice. Assyria is God's rod of judgment, but they will be punished for their pride. A remnant will return to the Mighty God.
chapterSummaries.11: The messianic king from Jesse's root will rule with righteousness and justice. The Spirit will rest on Him. In His kingdom, the wolf will lie with the lamb. He will gather the dispersed of Israel and Judah.
chapterSummaries.12: A song of salvation and thanksgiving for God's deliverance. The redeemed will draw water from the wells of salvation with joy and praise the Holy One of Israel among all peoples.
chapterSummaries.13: Oracle against Babylon. The day of the Lord comes with wrath and fierce anger. Babylon's pride will be brought low, and the city will become like Sodom and Gomorrah, uninhabited forever.
chapterSummaries.14: Israel will be restored and rule over their oppressors. The king of Babylon falls from heaven like Lucifer. His pride and ambition to be like God brings his downfall. Philistia is also warned of coming judgment.
chapterSummaries.15: Prophecy against Moab. Their cities will be destroyed in one night. The people flee as refugees, mourning their devastation. Even Isaiah's heart cries out for Moab in their distress.
chapterSummaries.16: Moab seeks refuge in Zion during their time of judgment. The Moabites are advised to send tribute to Jerusalem. Their pride will be humbled, and their glory will come to an end within three years.
chapterSummaries.17: Damascus and Israel will be destroyed together because they forgot the God of their salvation. Though they plant pleasant plants, the harvest will be a day of grief and incurable pain.
chapterSummaries.18: A message to the land beyond the rivers of Cush (Ethiopia). God will watch and act at the proper time. When the harvest is ready, He will cut down His enemies and bring tribute to Mount Zion.
chapterSummaries.19: Egypt's judgment as their gods fail and civil war breaks out. The Nile will dry up and their economy collapse. Yet Egypt will know the Lord, and Israel, Egypt, and Assyria will worship together.
chapterSummaries.20: Isaiah walks naked and barefoot for three years as a sign of Egypt and Ethiopia's coming captivity by Assyria. Those who trust in these nations instead of God will be ashamed and disappointed.
chapterSummaries.21: The fall of Babylon is announced. The watchman reports the collapse of Babylon's gods. Dumah (Edom) and Arabia also face judgment. Arabia's glory will fail within a year.
chapterSummaries.22: The valley of vision - Jerusalem's false confidence in their defenses instead of trusting in God. When judgment comes, they feast instead of repent. Shebna is removed from office, and Eliakim is installed as a faithful steward.
chapterSummaries.23: Oracle against Tyre, the merchant city. Her trade networks will be broken, and she will be forgotten for seventy years. Afterward, she will return to her trade and dedicate her profits to the Lord.
chapterSummaries.24: The earth is laid waste because its inhabitants have broken God's eternal covenant. The city of chaos is broken down. Yet the righteous remnant will sing from the ends of the earth of God's majesty.
chapterSummaries.25: A song of praise for God's deliverance. He destroys the stronghold of ruthless nations and provides a feast for all peoples. Death itself will be swallowed up forever, and tears wiped from all faces.
chapterSummaries.26: A song of salvation for the strong city with salvation as its walls. The righteous enter through its gates. God brings down the proud city and establishes peace for those who trust in the everlasting Rock.
chapterSummaries.27: The Lord will punish Leviathan and the dragon of the sea. Israel is God's vineyard that He guards and waters. The scattered people will be gathered to worship at the holy mountain in Jerusalem.
chapterSummaries.28: Woe to the drunkards of Ephraim whose fading crown will be trampled. God will be a crown of glory to the remnant. The cornerstone is laid in Zion for those who believe. Judgment will sweep away lies.
chapterSummaries.29: Ariel (Jerusalem) will be besieged and brought low, speaking from the dust. Their enemies will be like a dream that vanishes. The people honor God with their lips while their hearts are far away. Wisdom will return.
chapterSummaries.30: Woe to the rebellious children who make plans without God's counsel and seek Egypt's help. They reject God's word and want smooth lies. Though God waits to be gracious, judgment must come first before restoration.
chapterSummaries.31: Woe to those who go to Egypt for help instead of looking to the Holy One of Israel. Egypt's horses are flesh, not spirit. God will defend Jerusalem like birds flying overhead, protecting and delivering.
chapterSummaries.32: A king will reign in righteousness, and princes will rule with justice. The Spirit will transform the wilderness into a fruitful field. Peace and security will be the fruit of righteousness forever.
chapterSummaries.33: Woe to the destroyer who will himself be destroyed. God will arise and be exalted. He fills Zion with justice and righteousness. The king in his beauty will be seen, and Jerusalem will be a quiet dwelling.
chapterSummaries.34: God's judgment on all nations, especially Edom. The land will become a wasteland inhabited by wild animals. God's book records all this, and His Spirit will gather them. The sword is bathed in heaven for judgment.
chapterSummaries.35: The wilderness and desert will bloom and be glad. The weak will be strengthened, and the fearful encouraged. Waters will spring up in the desert. The redeemed will walk on the Highway of Holiness to Zion with joy.
chapterSummaries.36: Sennacherib's invasion and Rabshakeh's blasphemous threats against Jerusalem and Hezekiah. The Assyrian commander mocks God and tries to turn the people against their king through propaganda and psychological warfare.
chapterSummaries.37: Hezekiah receives Isaiah's prophecy and prays to God. Isaiah prophesies Sennacherib's defeat and death. God's angel destroys 185,000 Assyrians in one night. Sennacherib returns to Nineveh and is murdered by his sons.
chapterSummaries.38: Hezekiah's illness and recovery after Isaiah's prophecy of death. The king prays desperately, and God grants him fifteen more years. The sun's shadow moves backward as a sign. Hezekiah's psalm of thanksgiving for healing.
chapterSummaries.39: Babylonian envoys visit Hezekiah during his recovery. The proud king shows them all his treasures. Isaiah prophesies that everything will be carried to Babylon, and some of his sons will become eunuchs there.
chapterSummaries.40: Comfort God's people! Their warfare is ended, and their sin pardoned. Prepare the way of the Lord in the wilderness. All flesh is grass, but God's word stands forever. God feeds His flock like a shepherd.
chapterSummaries.41: God challenges the idols to prove their power by predicting the future. He has raised up Cyrus from the east to accomplish His purposes. Israel is God's chosen servant whom He will help and not forsake.
chapterSummaries.42: The first Servant Song - God's chosen one will bring justice to the nations gently and faithfully. God calls His people to be a light to the nations but they have become blind and deaf to His purposes.
chapterSummaries.43: Fear not, for God has redeemed Israel. They will pass through waters and fire safely. God will gather them from all directions. They are His witnesses that He alone is God and Savior.
chapterSummaries.44: God will pour His Spirit on Israel's offspring like water on thirsty ground. He formed them and will help them. The folly of idolatry is exposed - making gods from the same wood used for cooking fires.
chapterSummaries.45: Cyrus is God's anointed to subdue nations and rebuild Jerusalem. God alone is creator and sovereign. He forms light and darkness, makes peace and creates calamity. Let righteousness spring up from the earth.
chapterSummaries.46: Babylon's idols Bel and Nebo are carried away by beasts while God carries His people. He declares the end from the beginning. His counsel will stand, and He will call a bird of prey (Cyrus) from the east.
chapterSummaries.47: Babylon, the virgin daughter, will sit in the dust as a slave. Her sorceries and enchantments cannot save her from sudden destruction. She trusted in her wickedness saying, 'No one sees me,' but judgment comes.
chapterSummaries.48: God calls stubborn Israel to listen. He declared things long ago because He knew they were treacherous. For His name's sake, He restrains His anger. Come out of Babylon - the Lord has redeemed Jacob.
chapterSummaries.49: The second Servant Song - called from the womb to restore Israel and be a light to the nations. Though Israel seems forgotten, God will not forget them. Kings will bow down to the Holy One of Israel.
chapterSummaries.50: Where is the divorce certificate? Israel was sold for their iniquities. The third Servant Song - He gives His back to those who strike and does not hide from shame, knowing God helps Him.
chapterSummaries.51: Listen, you who pursue righteousness! Look to Abraham your father. God will comfort Zion and make her wilderness like Eden. His salvation will be forever, but the heavens will vanish like smoke.
chapterSummaries.52: Awake, Zion, and put on beautiful garments! Shake off the dust and break free from bondage. How beautiful are the feet of those who bring good news! All will see God's salvation.
chapterSummaries.53: The fourth Servant Song - the suffering servant despised and rejected by men. He bore our griefs and carried our sorrows. By His wounds we are healed. He was cut off for our transgressions.
chapterSummaries.54: Sing, barren woman! Your children will be more than those of the married woman. God will gather you with great compassion. His kindness will not depart, and His covenant of peace will not be removed.
chapterSummaries.55: Come to the waters, everyone who thirsts! Buy wine and milk without money. Seek the Lord while He may be found. His thoughts and ways are higher than ours. His word will accomplish its purpose.
chapterSummaries.56: Maintain justice and do righteousness, for God's salvation is near. Foreigners and eunuchs who keep His covenant will have a place in His house. It will be called a house of prayer for all nations.
chapterSummaries.57: The righteous perish while no one understands. Israel commits adultery with idols on every high hill. Yet God dwells with the contrite and humble to revive their hearts and heal their backslidings.
chapterSummaries.58: True fasting that God desires is not religious ritual but breaking chains of injustice, sharing bread with the hungry, and caring for the oppressed. Then your light will shine like the dawn.
chapterSummaries.59: God's hand is not too short to save, but sins separate people from Him. He sees the lack of justice and intervenes with His own arm. He comes as Redeemer to those who turn from transgression.
chapterSummaries.60: Arise, shine, for your light has come! Nations will come to your light and kings to your brightness. The wealth of nations will flow to you, and you will know that the Lord is your Savior.
chapterSummaries.61: The Spirit of the Lord is upon me to preach good news to the poor, bind up the brokenhearted, and proclaim liberty to captives. You will be called oaks of righteousness, priests of the Lord.
chapterSummaries.62: For Zion's sake I will not keep silent until her vindication shines like the dawn. You will be called by a new name and be a crown of beauty in God's hand. You will never again be forsaken.
chapterSummaries.63: Who is this coming from Edom in crimson garments? It is God who speaks in righteousness, mighty to save. He has trodden the winepress alone. Isaiah recalls God's loving kindness and mercy to Israel.
chapterSummaries.64: Oh that You would rend the heavens and come down! We have all become like one who is unclean. Yet You are our Father, and we are the clay. Your holy cities are a wilderness, and Your temple is burned.
chapterSummaries.65: God was ready to be found by those who did not seek Him. He will create new heavens and a new earth. Former things will not be remembered. There will be no more weeping or cries of distress.
chapterSummaries.66: Heaven is God's throne and earth His footstool - what house could contain Him? He looks to the humble and contrite. Before Zion travailed, she gave birth. All nations will come to see His glory and worship.

chapterSummaries.1: God calls Jeremiah as a prophet, assuring him of His presence and giving him authority over nations to uproot and to plant.
chapterSummaries.2: God accuses Israel of forsaking Him, the fountain of living waters, for worthless idols. Their unfaithfulness is exposed.
chapterSummaries.3: God likens Israel’s idolatry to adultery. Yet He calls them to return, promising restoration if they repent.
chapterSummaries.4: Jeremiah warns of coming judgment through invasion. Disaster from the north is imminent due to Israel’s sins.
chapterSummaries.5: God condemns widespread corruption. Both poor and rich reject Him. Prophets and priests deceive the people.
chapterSummaries.6: Jerusalem’s destruction is announced. Despite warnings, the people refuse correction. Their sacrifices are worthless to God.
chapterSummaries.7: Jeremiah delivers the temple sermon, warning that rituals cannot replace obedience. Shiloh’s fate warns Jerusalem.
chapterSummaries.8: The people persist in lies and refuse to repent. Jeremiah grieves over their incurable wound.
chapterSummaries.9: Jeremiah laments deceit and idolatry. God warns that trusting in wisdom, might, or riches is worthless—boasting must be in knowing Him.
chapterSummaries.10: Idols are worthless compared to the living God. Judgment is certain, and Jeremiah prays for correction.
chapterSummaries.11: God recalls the covenant with Israel. Conspiracy against Jeremiah arises; God promises judgment on the people.
chapterSummaries.12: Jeremiah questions why the wicked prosper. God challenges him to endure greater trials and foretells judgment on nations.
chapterSummaries.13: A ruined linen belt symbolizes Judah’s pride. Drunkenness and captivity are foretold. The people are urged to repent.
chapterSummaries.14: A drought devastates the land. False prophets deceive, but Jeremiah intercedes. God declares judgment unavoidable.
chapterSummaries.15: God tells Jeremiah not to pray for the people. Jeremiah laments his calling, but God reassures him of His presence.
chapterSummaries.16: Jeremiah is commanded not to marry, symbolizing coming judgment. Future restoration is promised when God gathers His people.
chapterSummaries.17: Trust in man leads to curse; trust in God leads to blessing. The heart is deceitful. Jeremiah prays for deliverance.
chapterSummaries.18: The potter’s house illustrates God’s sovereignty. Judah resists His shaping and plots against Jeremiah.
chapterSummaries.19: Jeremiah breaks a clay jar at Topheth, symbolizing Jerusalem’s coming destruction.
chapterSummaries.20: Jeremiah is beaten and mocked by Pashhur. He laments his suffering yet reaffirms God’s word burning within him.
chapterSummaries.21: God tells King Zedekiah that Jerusalem will fall to Babylon. Only surrender ensures life.
chapterSummaries.22: Jeremiah warns Judah’s kings to do justice or face ruin. Jehoiakim and Coniah are condemned.
chapterSummaries.23: False prophets are condemned. God promises a righteous Branch from David’s line who will reign as king.
chapterSummaries.24: Two baskets of figs symbolize exiles: good figs represent those in exile who will be restored; bad figs represent those who remain and will perish.
chapterSummaries.25: Judah’s seventy years of exile are foretold. Nations will also drink God’s cup of wrath.
chapterSummaries.26: Jeremiah’s temple sermon leads to threats of death, but some defend him, recalling past prophets.
chapterSummaries.27: Jeremiah wears a yoke, urging submission to Babylon. False prophets contradict him.
chapterSummaries.28: Hananiah falsely prophesies peace and breaks Jeremiah’s yoke. Jeremiah declares Babylon’s yoke will be iron. Hananiah dies as foretold.
chapterSummaries.29: Jeremiah’s letter to exiles urges them to seek peace in Babylon and trust God’s promise of future restoration.
chapterSummaries.30: God promises restoration and a new covenant. Israel’s captivity will end, and David’s line will reign.
chapterSummaries.31: The new covenant is promised: God’s law written on hearts, forgiveness of sins, and restoration of Israel.
chapterSummaries.32: Jeremiah buys a field while imprisoned, symbolizing future hope and restoration despite Jerusalem’s siege.
chapterSummaries.33: God reaffirms His covenant with David and Levi. Future restoration and prosperity are promised.
chapterSummaries.34: Judah breaks its covenant to free slaves. God announces destruction because of their unfaithfulness.
chapterSummaries.35: The Rechabites’ faithfulness contrasts with Judah’s disobedience. God promises blessing to them.
chapterSummaries.36: Jeremiah dictates God’s words to Baruch. King Jehoiakim burns the scroll. Jeremiah dictates another scroll with added words.
chapterSummaries.37: Jeremiah warns Zedekiah of Babylon’s victory. He is arrested and imprisoned on false charges.
chapterSummaries.38: Jeremiah is thrown into a cistern but rescued by Ebed-Melek. He tells Zedekiah to surrender or face destruction.
chapterSummaries.39: Jerusalem falls to Babylon. Zedekiah is captured. Jeremiah is spared and released by the Babylonians.
chapterSummaries.40: Gedaliah is appointed governor. He urges peace, but Ishmael plots against him.
chapterSummaries.41: Ishmael assassinates Gedaliah and slaughters many, then is pursued and defeated by Johanan.
chapterSummaries.42: Survivors ask Jeremiah for guidance but disobey God’s word, choosing to flee to Egypt.
chapterSummaries.43: The people forcibly take Jeremiah to Egypt. He prophesies Babylon’s conquest of Egypt.
chapterSummaries.44: Jeremiah condemns the Jews in Egypt for idolatry. They refuse to listen, sealing their judgment.
chapterSummaries.45: A word to Baruch: though judgment is coming, God promises to preserve his life.
chapterSummaries.46: Prophecies against Egypt: God will punish Egypt, but later restore it.
chapterSummaries.47: Prophecy against the Philistines: they will be devastated by Babylon.
chapterSummaries.48: Prophecy against Moab: its pride will bring destruction, though restoration is promised in the future.
chapterSummaries.49: Prophecies against Ammon, Edom, Damascus, Kedar, Hazor, and Elam: they will be judged but some restored.
chapterSummaries.50: Prophecy against Babylon: it will fall as God redeems Israel.
chapterSummaries.51: God’s judgment on Babylon is confirmed. Babylon will sink, never to rise again.
chapterSummaries.52: Jerusalem falls as in 2 Kings. The temple is destroyed, and the people exiled. Jehoiachin is later released in Babylon.

chapterSummaries.1: Jerusalem, once full of people, sits desolate. She weeps bitterly over her destruction, confessing her sins as the cause of her suffering.
chapterSummaries.2: God’s anger has brought ruin to Zion. The temple and city are destroyed. The people mourn as children and priests perish.
chapterSummaries.3: Jeremiah laments deep personal suffering but finds hope in God’s steadfast love and mercies, which are new every morning.
chapterSummaries.4: The horrors of Jerusalem’s siege are described: famine, cruelty, and the downfall of princes. God’s wrath has been poured out fully.
chapterSummaries.5: A communal prayer pleads for God’s mercy and restoration. The people confess their suffering and call on God not to forget them.

chapterSummaries.1: Ezekiel sees a vision of God’s glory: four living creatures and wheels within wheels, radiant with God’s presence.
chapterSummaries.2: God commissions Ezekiel as a prophet to a rebellious Israel, calling him to speak His words whether they listen or not.
chapterSummaries.3: Ezekiel eats the scroll, symbolizing God’s message within him. He is appointed as a watchman responsible to warn Israel.
chapterSummaries.4: Ezekiel enacts a siege against Jerusalem with symbolic actions, lying on his sides and eating rationed food.
chapterSummaries.5: Ezekiel cuts his hair to symbolize Jerusalem’s fate: some burned, some struck, some scattered, all under God’s judgment.
chapterSummaries.6: Prophecy against Israel’s mountains: idolatrous high places will be destroyed, but a remnant will survive.
chapterSummaries.7: The end has come for Israel. Disaster, doom, and God’s wrath will fall because of their sins.
chapterSummaries.8: Ezekiel sees visions of abominations in the temple: idolatry and corruption provoking God’s judgment.
chapterSummaries.9: God commands angels to mark the faithful, while others are struck down in judgment. God’s glory begins departing.
chapterSummaries.10: Ezekiel sees God’s glory departing the temple, with cherubim and wheels full of fire.
chapterSummaries.11: Leaders are condemned for wickedness. God promises judgment, but also future restoration and a new heart for His people.
chapterSummaries.12: Ezekiel enacts exile by packing belongings. God announces that exile and judgment are certain and near.
chapterSummaries.13: False prophets and prophetesses are condemned for lying visions and false security.
chapterSummaries.14: Idolatrous elders are rebuked. Even Noah, Daniel, and Job could only save themselves by righteousness.
chapterSummaries.15: Jerusalem is compared to a useless vine, destined only for fire.
chapterSummaries.16: Jerusalem is portrayed as an unfaithful wife who prostituted herself with idols. Yet God promises eventual restoration.
chapterSummaries.17: A parable of two eagles and a vine symbolizes Judah’s alliances. God promises to plant a righteous Branch.
chapterSummaries.18: Each person is responsible for their own sin. The righteous live; the wicked die. God desires repentance, not death.
chapterSummaries.19: A lament for Israel’s princes, portrayed as young lions and a withered vine.
chapterSummaries.20: God recounts Israel’s rebellion from Egypt onward. Yet He promises to restore them for His name’s sake.
chapterSummaries.21: God’s sword of judgment is unsheathed against Jerusalem and Ammon.
chapterSummaries.22: Jerusalem is condemned for bloodshed, idolatry, and corruption. Leaders, priests, and prophets are all corrupt.
chapterSummaries.23: The allegory of two sisters, Oholah and Oholibah, represents Israel and Judah’s unfaithfulness with foreign nations.
chapterSummaries.24: The siege of Jerusalem begins. Ezekiel uses a boiling pot as a sign. His wife dies, and he cannot mourn, symbolizing the people’s shock.
chapterSummaries.25: Judgment is proclaimed on Ammon, Moab, Edom, and Philistia for their hostility toward Israel.
chapterSummaries.26: Prophecy against Tyre: it will be destroyed by many nations and become bare rock.
chapterSummaries.27: A lament over Tyre’s wealth and trade, now destined for ruin.
chapterSummaries.28: Judgment against the pride of Tyre’s ruler. A prophecy of lamentation against Sidon. God promises restoration for Israel.
chapterSummaries.29: Judgment against Egypt: it will be desolate for forty years, then restored but never great again.
chapterSummaries.30: The day of the Lord against Egypt and her allies: devastation and ruin are decreed.
chapterSummaries.31: Assyria is likened to a great cedar, felled because of pride. Egypt will share its fate.
chapterSummaries.32: A lament for Pharaoh, likening him to a fallen monster. Egypt will descend to the grave with other nations.
chapterSummaries.33: Ezekiel is appointed a watchman again. Each person is accountable. News arrives that Jerusalem has fallen.
chapterSummaries.34: God condemns Israel’s shepherds (leaders). He promises to shepherd His people Himself and to raise up a Davidic shepherd.
chapterSummaries.35: Judgment against Mount Seir (Edom) for perpetual hostility toward Israel.
chapterSummaries.36: God promises restoration for Israel’s land and people. He will give them a new heart and spirit.
chapterSummaries.37: The valley of dry bones symbolizes Israel’s restoration. Two sticks become one, symbolizing a reunited nation under David’s king.
chapterSummaries.38: Prophecy against Gog of Magog: a future invasion of Israel will be destroyed by God’s power.
chapterSummaries.39: Gog’s armies are defeated and buried. God’s glory is revealed among the nations.
chapterSummaries.40: Ezekiel sees a vision of a new temple, with detailed measurements and descriptions.
chapterSummaries.41: The temple’s interior is described in detail, with decorations and measurements.
chapterSummaries.42: Chambers for priests are described, emphasizing holiness and separation.
chapterSummaries.43: God’s glory returns to the temple. Instructions for the altar and sacrifices are given.
chapterSummaries.44: Regulations for the temple: the prince and priests have specific roles. The Levites are warned for past unfaithfulness.
chapterSummaries.45: Land is divided: a portion for the Lord, priests, Levites, and the prince. Regulations for offerings are given.
chapterSummaries.46: The prince has specific worship responsibilities. Regulations for offerings and temple use are given.
chapterSummaries.47: Ezekiel sees water flowing from the temple, bringing life to the land. Land boundaries are described.
chapterSummaries.48: The land is divided among the tribes. The city and temple are described. The city is named: “The Lord is There.”

chapterSummaries.1: Daniel and his friends are taken to Babylon. They refuse the king’s food, choosing vegetables and water. God blesses them with wisdom and health.
chapterSummaries.2: Nebuchadnezzar dreams of a great statue. Daniel interprets it as successive kingdoms, ending with God’s eternal kingdom. The king honors Daniel.
chapterSummaries.3: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego refuse to worship the golden image. They are thrown into a fiery furnace but delivered unharmed by God.
chapterSummaries.4: Nebuchadnezzar dreams of a great tree cut down. Daniel interprets it as the king’s humbling. Nebuchadnezzar becomes insane, then restored, praising God.
chapterSummaries.5: Belshazzar’s feast desecrates sacred vessels. A hand writes on the wall: “MENE, MENE, TEKEL, PARSIN.” Daniel interprets. That night Babylon falls.
chapterSummaries.6: Daniel prays despite a decree against it. He is thrown into the lions’ den but God delivers him. Darius honors Daniel’s God.
chapterSummaries.7: Daniel dreams of four beasts representing kingdoms. The Ancient of Days judges, and the Son of Man receives an everlasting kingdom.
chapterSummaries.8: Daniel sees a vision of a ram and a goat, symbolizing Medo-Persia and Greece. The little horn arises, foreshadowing oppression.
chapterSummaries.9: Daniel prays a confession for Israel. Gabriel reveals the prophecy of seventy weeks, pointing to the Messiah and future desolation.
chapterSummaries.10: Daniel has a vision of a glorious man. He is strengthened to hear prophecies of great conflict to come.
chapterSummaries.11: A detailed prophecy of conflicts between kings of the North and South unfolds, leading to a contemptible ruler and great persecution.
chapterSummaries.12: The end times are described: Michael will arise, resurrection will occur, and the righteous will shine. Daniel is told to seal the words until the end.

chapterSummaries.1: God commands Hosea to marry Gomer, symbolizing Israel’s unfaithfulness. Their children’s names signify judgment: Jezreel, Lo-Ruhamah, and Lo-Ammi.
chapterSummaries.2: God describes Israel as an unfaithful wife. Yet He promises to allure her back, betrothing her forever in righteousness and love.
chapterSummaries.3: Hosea redeems Gomer, showing God’s love for Israel despite their unfaithfulness. Israel will be restored after a period without king or sacrifice.
chapterSummaries.4: God brings charges against Israel: no faithfulness, love, or knowledge of Him. Priests and people alike are corrupt.
chapterSummaries.5: Israel and Judah are condemned for unfaithfulness. God withdraws, waiting for their repentance.
chapterSummaries.6: Israel offers shallow repentance. God desires steadfast love, not sacrifice. Their loyalty fades quickly.
chapterSummaries.7: Israel is compared to a hot oven of sin, filled with intrigue and alliances with foreign nations instead of God.
chapterSummaries.8: Israel has sown the wind and will reap the whirlwind. Idols and foreign alliances will bring destruction.
chapterSummaries.9: Israel’s joy turns to mourning. Exile is coming as punishment for their idolatry and wickedness.
chapterSummaries.10: Israel is a spreading vine but uses prosperity for idolatry. Judgment will come; they will be exiled and their king removed.
chapterSummaries.11: God recalls His love in calling Israel out of Egypt. Though they turn away, His compassion prevails, promising restoration.
chapterSummaries.12: Israel is deceitful like Jacob. God reminds them of His faithfulness, urging them to return in love and justice.
chapterSummaries.13: Israel’s idolatry brings death and destruction. God declares judgment but also promises ultimate redemption from death.
chapterSummaries.14: A call to repentance: Israel is urged to return to God. He promises healing, love, and flourishing for the repentant.

chapterSummaries.1: A devastating locust plague strikes the land. Joel calls the people, priests, and elders to lament and fast before the Lord.
chapterSummaries.2: A greater day of the Lord is described, with invading armies like locusts. Yet God calls His people to return with repentance, promising restoration and the outpouring of His Spirit.
chapterSummaries.3: God gathers the nations for judgment in the Valley of Jehoshaphat. He defends His people, promises blessing for Zion, and declares that the Lord dwells in Jerusalem.

chapterSummaries.1: Amos proclaims God’s judgment on surrounding nations—Damascus, Gaza, Tyre, Edom, Ammon—for cruelty and violence.
chapterSummaries.2: Judgment is declared on Moab, Judah, and Israel. Israel is condemned for injustice, oppression, and idolatry.
chapterSummaries.3: God declares judgment on Israel because they alone were chosen and yet rebelled. Calamity comes by His hand.
chapterSummaries.4: Israel is warned for oppressing the poor and practicing false worship. God sent calamities, yet they did not return to Him.
chapterSummaries.5: A lament for Israel: seek the Lord and live. God hates empty rituals but desires justice to roll like waters and righteousness like a stream.
chapterSummaries.6: Woe to the complacent in Zion. Israel’s pride will lead to destruction and exile.
chapterSummaries.7: Amos sees visions of judgment: locusts, fire, and a plumb line. Amaziah the priest opposes him, but Amos stands firm.
chapterSummaries.8: A vision of a basket of ripe fruit symbolizes Israel’s end. Injustice and greed bring God’s wrath; a famine of hearing God’s word is foretold.
chapterSummaries.9: God’s judgment is inescapable, yet He promises restoration: Israel will be replanted and never again uprooted.

chapterSummaries.1: Obadiah prophesies judgment against Edom for pride and violence against Israel. The day of the Lord is near: nations will be judged, but deliverance and holiness will come to Zion.
God calls Jonah to preach against Nineveh. Jonah flees by ship, but God sends a storm. Jonah is thrown overboard and swallowed by a great fish.
chapterSummaries.2: From the fish’s belly, Jonah prays a prayer of repentance and thanksgiving. God commands the fish to vomit him onto dry land.
chapterSummaries.3: Jonah preaches in Nineveh. The people, from king to commoner, repent in sackcloth and fasting. God relents from destroying the city.
chapterSummaries.4: Jonah becomes angry at God’s mercy. God teaches him through a plant that His compassion extends to all people.

chapterSummaries.1: Micah proclaims God’s judgment on Samaria and Jerusalem for idolatry and sin. Their cities will face ruin.
chapterSummaries.2: Woe to those who oppress and seize land. False prophets promise ease, but judgment is coming. Yet God promises to gather a remnant.
chapterSummaries.3: Leaders and prophets are condemned for injustice and corruption. Zion will be plowed like a field because of their sins.
chapterSummaries.4: In the last days, nations will stream to the mountain of the Lord. God will bring peace, and the exiles will be restored.
chapterSummaries.5: A ruler will come from Bethlehem to shepherd God’s people in strength. Israel will triumph over enemies through God’s deliverance.
chapterSummaries.6: God brings a case against His people, asking what He has done wrong. True worship is to act justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God.
chapterSummaries.7: Micah laments corruption but hopes in God’s salvation. God will forgive and restore His people, showing steadfast love.

chapterSummaries.1: The Lord is a jealous and avenging God, slow to anger but mighty in power. He promises judgment on Nineveh but refuge for those who trust Him.
chapterSummaries.2: The fall of Nineveh is vividly described: the attackers advance, defenses collapse, and the city is plundered.
chapterSummaries.3: Woe to Nineveh, the city of blood. Her cruelty and idolatry bring shame and destruction. None will mourn her fall.

chapterSummaries.1: Habakkuk questions why God allows injustice. God responds that He is raising up the Babylonians to bring judgment.
chapterSummaries.2: Habakkuk waits for God’s answer. God declares woe to the proud and unjust but promises the righteous will live by faith.
chapterSummaries.3: Habakkuk prays, recalling God’s mighty deeds. Though facing hardship, he rejoices in the Lord as his strength and salvation.

chapterSummaries.1: Zephaniah announces the coming day of the Lord: judgment on Judah for idolatry and complacency. The whole earth will be consumed.
chapterSummaries.2: A call to seek the Lord before His anger falls. Judgment is pronounced on surrounding nations—Philistia, Moab, Ammon, Cush, and Assyria.
chapterSummaries.3: Jerusalem is condemned for rebellion and corruption, but God promises to purify the nations. A humble remnant will rejoice as God restores His people.

chapterSummaries.1: Through Haggai, God rebukes the people for neglecting the temple while focusing on their own houses. The leaders and people obey and begin rebuilding.
chapterSummaries.2: God encourages the builders, promising His glory will fill the temple. He assures blessing for obedience and foretells Zerubbabel’s significance in His plan.

chapterSummaries.1: Zechariah calls the people to return to the Lord. He sees visions of horsemen patrolling the earth and God’s promise to restore Jerusalem.
chapterSummaries.2: A vision of a man measuring Jerusalem: God will be its protection and glory. Exiles are urged to return, for God will dwell among His people.
chapterSummaries.3: Joshua the high priest stands accused but is cleansed and clothed in righteousness. God promises His servant, the Branch.
chapterSummaries.4: Zechariah sees a golden lampstand and two olive trees, symbolizing God’s Spirit empowering Zerubbabel to rebuild the temple.
chapterSummaries.5: A flying scroll symbolizes judgment on thieves and liars. A woman in a basket represents wickedness being carried away.
chapterSummaries.6: Four chariots symbolize God’s judgment on the nations. Joshua the high priest is crowned, pointing to the coming Branch who will rule and build God’s temple.
chapterSummaries.7: God rebukes empty fasting. True worship is justice, mercy, and compassion.
chapterSummaries.8: God promises to bless Jerusalem with peace, prosperity, and truth. Many nations will come to seek the Lord.
chapterSummaries.9: Judgment is proclaimed on Israel’s enemies. A humble king, riding on a donkey, is promised to bring peace to the nations.
chapterSummaries.10: God promises to strengthen and restore His people, gathering them from exile and blessing them abundantly.
chapterSummaries.11: Zechariah acts as a shepherd, symbolizing Israel’s rejection of God’s true shepherd. Thirty pieces of silver foreshadow betrayal of the Messiah.
chapterSummaries.12: God promises to defend Jerusalem. He will pour out a spirit of grace and supplication, and the people will mourn for the one they pierced.
chapterSummaries.13: A fountain is opened to cleanse from sin. Idols and false prophets are removed. The Shepherd is struck, and the sheep are scattered.
chapterSummaries.14: The day of the Lord: nations gather against Jerusalem, but the Lord comes to reign as King over all the earth. Jerusalem will be secure, and all nations will worship the Lord.

chapterSummaries.1: God declares His love for Israel but rebukes the priests for offering defiled sacrifices. His name will be great among the nations.
chapterSummaries.2: The priests are warned for corrupt teaching. God condemns unfaithfulness in marriage and calls for covenant faithfulness.
chapterSummaries.3: God promises to send His messenger before the Lord’s coming. He calls Israel to return to Him and rebukes them for withholding tithes. A distinction is made between the righteous and the wicked.
chapterSummaries.4: The day of the Lord is coming, burning like fire for the wicked but bringing healing for the righteous. Elijah will come before the great and dreadful day of the Lord.

chapterSummaries.1: Jesus' genealogy proves He's the promised Messiah; virgin Mary conceives by the Holy Spirit; Joseph obeys God's angel.
chapterSummaries.2: Wise men worship infant Jesus; jealous Herod massacres Bethlehem's babies; the family flees to Egypt, fulfilling prophecy.
chapterSummaries.3: John the Baptist prepares the way for Messiah; Jesus is baptized, receiving the Spirit and the Father's approval.
chapterSummaries.4: Satan tempts Jesus in the wilderness for 40 days; Jesus resists with Scripture and begins His Galilean ministry.
chapterSummaries.5: Jesus teaches the Beatitudes and kingdom principles; believers are salt and light; righteousness exceeds that of Pharisees.
chapterSummaries.6: Jesus teaches about authentic worship: giving, prayer, and fasting are for God's glory, not human recognition.
chapterSummaries.7: Don't judge others harshly; ask God persistently; the narrow gate leads to life; false prophets bear bad fruit.
chapterSummaries.8: Jesus demonstrates His authority by healing leprosy, paralysis, fever, and storms; the cost of discipleship is high.
chapterSummaries.9: Jesus heals a paralytic, calls Matthew, raises the dead, heals bleeding and blindness; workers are few but harvest is plentiful.
chapterSummaries.10: Jesus commissions the twelve apostles to preach to Israel; persecution will come, but God will vindicate the faithful.
chapterSummaries.11: John the Baptist questions Jesus from prison; Jesus pronounces woes on unrepentant cities but invites the weary to find rest in His gentle yoke.
chapterSummaries.12: Pharisees attack Jesus for Sabbath healing and grain-picking; they accuse Him of casting out demons by Beelzebul, but Jesus warns against blasphemy of the Spirit.
chapterSummaries.13: Jesus teaches kingdom parables: sower, weeds, mustard seed, hidden treasure, pearl, and net; only some understand these mysteries of heaven.
chapterSummaries.14: Herod beheads John the Baptist; Jesus feeds 5,000 with five loaves and two fish, then walks on water, calming the disciples' fears.
chapterSummaries.15: Jesus confronts Pharisees about their traditions that nullify God's commands; He heals the Canaanite woman's daughter and feeds 4,000 in the wilderness.
chapterSummaries.16: Pharisees seek a sign but receive only Jonah's; Peter confesses Jesus as the Messiah, receives keys to the kingdom, but rebukes Jesus' death prediction.
chapterSummaries.17: Jesus is transfigured before Peter, James, and John; Moses and Elijah appear; Jesus heals an epileptic boy and teaches about faith and His coming death.
chapterSummaries.18: Jesus teaches about greatness through childlike humility, church discipline for sin, and unlimited forgiveness illustrated by the unforgiving servant parable.
chapterSummaries.19: Jesus teaches about divorce, blesses children, and encounters the rich young ruler who cannot abandon his wealth for eternal life and perfect discipleship.
chapterSummaries.20: The parable of vineyard workers reveals God's gracious generosity; Jesus predicts His death a third time and teaches that greatness comes through servant leadership.
chapterSummaries.21: Jesus enters Jerusalem triumphantly, cleanses the temple of money-changers, curses the fruitless fig tree, and faces challenges to His divine authority.
chapterSummaries.22: Jesus tells the wedding feast parable, answers questions about taxes to Caesar, resurrection with seven brothers, and identifies love as the greatest commandment.
chapterSummaries.23: Jesus pronounces seven woes against the scribes and Pharisees for their hypocrisy, calling them whitewashed tombs, and laments over Jerusalem's rejection.
chapterSummaries.24: Jesus predicts the temple's destruction and describes signs of His second coming, urging watchfulness since no one knows the day or hour.
chapterSummaries.25: Three parables about readiness: ten virgins, talents, and sheep and goats; Jesus separates the righteous from the wicked in final judgment.
chapterSummaries.26: Jesus is anointed at Bethany, celebrates the Last Supper establishing the New Covenant, agonizes in Gethsemane, and is betrayed by Judas and arrested.
chapterSummaries.27: Judas hangs himself; Jesus faces trials before Pilate and is crucified between two thieves, dying as darkness covers the land and the temple veil tears.
chapterSummaries.28: Women discover the empty tomb; an angel announces Jesus' resurrection; Jesus appears to His disciples and gives the Great Commission to make disciples of all nations.

chapterSummaries.1: John baptizes Jesus; the Spirit descends; Jesus calls fishermen; teaches with authority; heals many.
chapterSummaries.2: Jesus heals paralytic; calls Levi; defends disciples' behavior on Sabbath and fasting.
chapterSummaries.3: Withered hand healed on Sabbath; twelve apostles chosen; Jesus accused of casting out demons by Beelzebul.
chapterSummaries.4: Parable of sower and others; Jesus calms the storm, showing power over nature.
chapterSummaries.5: Legion of demons cast into swine; Jairus' daughter raised; woman with bleeding healed.
chapterSummaries.6: Rejection in Nazareth; twelve sent out; John the Baptist beheaded; feeding of 5,000; Jesus walks on water.
chapterSummaries.7: Pharisees criticized for tradition over God's law; Syrophoenician woman's faith; deaf man healed.
chapterSummaries.8: Feeding 4,000; Pharisees seek sign; Peter confesses Jesus as Christ; cross predicted.
chapterSummaries.9: Transfiguration reveals Jesus' glory; boy with demon healed; greatness through service.
chapterSummaries.10: Divorce teaching; children blessed; rich young ruler; James and John's request; blind Bartimaeus healed.
chapterSummaries.11: Triumphal entry; temple cleansed; fig tree cursed; authority questioned.
chapterSummaries.12: Parable of vineyard tenants; taxes to Caesar; resurrection question; greatest commandment; widow's offering.
chapterSummaries.13: Temple's destruction predicted; signs of the end; perseverance encouraged; no one knows the hour.
chapterSummaries.14: Anointing at Bethany; Last Supper; Gethsemane agony; betrayal and arrest; Peter's denial.
chapterSummaries.15: Trial before Pilate; crucifixion between two thieves; Joseph of Arimathea buries Jesus.
chapterSummaries.16: Empty tomb; angel announces resurrection; women flee in fear; appearances to disciples; great commission.

chapterSummaries.1: Angel Gabriel announces Jesus' birth to Mary; Mary visits Elizabeth, praising God; Zechariah's song celebrates salvation for all people.
chapterSummaries.2: Jesus born in Bethlehem; angels announce good news to shepherds; Jesus presented in temple where Simeon and Anna recognize the Messiah.
chapterSummaries.3: John the Baptist calls all to repentance; Jesus baptized and affirmed by the Father; Luke traces Jesus' universal genealogy to Adam.
chapterSummaries.4: Satan tempts Jesus who responds with Scripture; Jesus begins ministry in Nazareth, proclaiming good news to the poor but facing rejection.
chapterSummaries.5: Jesus calls fishermen disciples; cleanses leper and paralytic, demonstrating power over sickness; calls tax collector Levi, dining with sinners.
chapterSummaries.6: Jesus teaches that mercy matters more than Sabbath rules; chooses twelve apostles; blesses the poor and marginalied in radical kingdom teaching.
chapterSummaries.7: Jesus heals centurion's servant and widow's son; John the Baptist questions from prison; Jesus defends ministry to outcasts and sinners.
chapterSummaries.8: Women support Jesus' ministry; parable of soils; Jesus calms storm and heals demon-possessed man, showing power over nature and evil.
chapterSummaries.9: Twelve sent to preach and heal; feeding of 5,000; Peter confesses Jesus as Messiah; transfiguration reveals Jesus' glory; journey to Jerusalem begins.
chapterSummaries.10: Seventy-two sent out with kingdom authority; Good Samaritan teaches love for neighbors; Mary chooses better portion while Martha serves anxiously.
chapterSummaries.11: Jesus teaches disciples to pray; delivers man from demon; religious leaders accuse Him of using Satan's power; warns against spiritual pride.
chapterSummaries.12: Jesus warns against hypocrisy; teaches about worry and wealth; calls disciples to readiness for His return and faithful stewardship.
chapterSummaries.13: Jesus calls all to repentance; heals bent woman on Sabbath; kingdom grows like mustard seed; narrow door requires urgent response.
chapterSummaries.14: Jesus heals on Sabbath; teaches humility at dinner; parables about discipleship's cost and the great banquet welcoming outcasts.
chapterSummaries.15: Three parables of lost things found: sheep, coin, and prodigal son, revealing God's heart for seeking and saving the lost.
chapterSummaries.16: Shrewd manager parable teaches faithful stewardship; rich man and Lazarus shows eternal consequences of ignoring the poor.
chapterSummaries.17: Jesus teaches about forgiveness, faith, and humble service; heals ten lepers but only Samaritan returns grateful; kingdom is within you.
chapterSummaries.18: Persistent widow and humble tax collector teach about prayer; Jesus welcomes children; rich ruler can't let go of wealth for eternal life.
chapterSummaries.19: Jesus saves tax collector Zacchaeus; parable of ten minas about faithful service; triumphal entry and temple cleansing in Jerusalem.
chapterSummaries.20: Religious leaders challenge Jesus' authority; parable of wicked tenants; questions about taxes, resurrection, and David's son confound opponents.
chapterSummaries.21: Widow's offering shows true generosity; Jesus predicts temple's destruction and His return; disciples must endure persecution with patient faith.
chapterSummaries.22: Judas betrays Jesus for money; Last Supper establishes new covenant; Jesus agonizes in prayer; arrested while disciples argue about greatness.
chapterSummaries.23: Jesus tried before Pilate and Herod; crucified between two criminals, showing mercy to repentant thief; buried by Joseph of Arimathea.
chapterSummaries.24: Women find empty tomb; Jesus appears on Emmaus road; shows disciples His wounds; explains Scripture; ascends after commissioning them as witnesses.

chapterSummaries.1: The Word became flesh; John the Baptist testifies to Jesus; first disciples called; Jesus is the Lamb of God.
chapterSummaries.2: Wedding at Cana: Jesus' first miracle; cleansing the temple shows His zeal for God's house.
chapterSummaries.3: Nicodemus learns about new birth; Jesus explains God's love and the necessity of believing in Him.
chapterSummaries.4: Samaritan woman at the well discovers living water; many Samaritans believe; official's son healed.
chapterSummaries.5: Lame man healed at pool of Bethesda on Sabbath; Jesus claims equality with the Father.
chapterSummaries.6: Feeding 5,000; walking on water; Jesus is the bread of life; many disciples turn away.
chapterSummaries.7: Jesus teaches at Feast of Tabernacles; division among people; living water promised to believers.
chapterSummaries.8: Woman caught in adultery; Jesus is the light of the world; truth sets free; Abraham rejoiced to see Jesus' day.
chapterSummaries.9: Man born blind receives sight; Pharisees investigate and expel him; Jesus reveals spiritual blindness.
chapterSummaries.10: Jesus is the good shepherd who lays down His life; sheep know His voice; unity with the Father.
chapterSummaries.11: Lazarus dies and is raised after four days; Martha confesses Jesus as Messiah; plot to kill Jesus intensifies.
chapterSummaries.12: Mary anoints Jesus' feet; triumphal entry; Jesus predicts His death and glorification; some Greeks seek Him.
chapterSummaries.13: Jesus washes disciples' feet; teaches about humble service; predicts betrayal; gives new commandment of love.
chapterSummaries.14: Jesus is the way, truth, and life; promises the Holy Spirit as Helper; peace amid trouble.
chapterSummaries.15: Jesus is the true vine; believers must remain in Him to bear fruit; world will hate His followers.
chapterSummaries.16: Holy Spirit will convict the world; sorrow will turn to joy; Jesus has overcome the world.
chapterSummaries.17: Jesus' high priestly prayer for Himself, His disciples, and all future believers; unity and glory.
chapterSummaries.18: Betrayal and arrest in garden; trials before Annas, Caiaphas, and Pilate; Peter's denials.
chapterSummaries.19: Jesus scourged and crucified; 'It is finished'; buried in Joseph's new tomb; Sabbath approaches.
chapterSummaries.20: Empty tomb; Jesus appears to Mary, then disciples; Thomas believes; these signs written for faith.
chapterSummaries.21: Miraculous catch of fish; Jesus restores Peter with threefold commissioning to feed His sheep.

chapterSummaries.1: Jesus ascends to heaven after commanding the apostles to wait for the Holy Spirit and be witnesses to the ends of the earth. Matthias is chosen to replace Judas among the twelve apostles.
chapterSummaries.2: The Holy Spirit comes upon the apostles at Pentecost, enabling them to speak in different languages. Peter preaches boldly, and about 3,000 people are baptized and added to the church.
chapterSummaries.3: Peter and John heal a lame man at the temple gate, drawing a crowd to whom Peter preaches about Jesus as the promised Messiah. The healing demonstrates God's power working through the apostles.
chapterSummaries.4: Peter and John are arrested for preaching about Jesus but boldly defend their faith before the religious authorities. The early church prays for boldness and continues to grow in unity and power.
chapterSummaries.5: Ananias and Sapphira die for lying to the Holy Spirit about their offering, demonstrating God's holiness. The apostles perform many signs and wonders despite increasing persecution from religious leaders.
chapterSummaries.6: Seven deacons, including Stephen, are chosen to serve the church and care for widows. Stephen performs great wonders and faces opposition from those who cannot refute his Spirit-filled wisdom.
chapterSummaries.7: Stephen delivers a powerful speech tracing Israel's history and accusing the religious leaders of rejecting God's messengers. He becomes the first Christian martyr, stoned to death while Saul watches approvingly.
chapterSummaries.8: Persecution scatters Christians throughout Judea and Samaria, spreading the gospel beyond Jerusalem. Philip preaches in Samaria and baptizes an Ethiopian eunuch, showing the gospel reaching all nations.
chapterSummaries.9: Saul encounters the risen Christ on the road to Damascus and is dramatically converted from persecutor to preacher. Ananias baptizes Saul, who immediately begins proclaiming Jesus as the Son of God.
chapterSummaries.10: God gives Peter a vision about clean and unclean foods, preparing him to preach to Cornelius, a Gentile centurion. The Holy Spirit falls on Cornelius and his household, proving that salvation is for all people.
chapterSummaries.11: Peter defends his ministry to Gentiles before the Jerusalem church, explaining God's clear leading through visions and the Spirit's work. The church in Antioch grows and becomes the first place where believers are called Christians.
chapterSummaries.12: King Herod persecutes the church, executing James and imprisoning Peter, but an angel miraculously frees Peter from prison. Herod dies under God's judgment, while the word of God continues to spread.
chapterSummaries.13: The Holy Spirit sends Barnabas and Saul (Paul) on their first missionary journey from Antioch. They preach in Cyprus and Pisidian Antioch, where Paul delivers his first recorded sermon about Jesus as the promised Savior.
chapterSummaries.14: Paul and Barnabas continue their missionary work in Iconium, Lystra, and Derbe, facing both acceptance and persecution. They strengthen new believers and appoint elders before returning to Antioch to report on God's work among the Gentiles.
chapterSummaries.15: The Jerusalem Council meets to decide whether Gentile converts must follow Jewish law, concluding that salvation is by grace alone. This pivotal decision opens the door for the gospel to spread freely among all nations.
chapterSummaries.16: Paul begins his second missionary journey with Silas, traveling through Asia Minor and receiving the Macedonian call to Europe. In Philippi, Lydia becomes a believer and Paul and Silas are miraculously freed from prison.
chapterSummaries.17: Paul preaches in Thessalonica and Berea, then travels to Athens where he delivers his famous sermon about the unknown God. Some mock his message about resurrection, but others believe and join him.
chapterSummaries.18: Paul spends 18 months in Corinth, working with Aquila and Priscilla while establishing a strong church. Despite opposition, God encourages Paul in a vision to continue speaking boldly.
chapterSummaries.19: Paul ministers in Ephesus for over two years, performing extraordinary miracles and seeing many turn from magic and idolatry to Christ. A riot erupts when silversmiths fear losing business from decreased idol worship.
chapterSummaries.20: Paul travels through Macedonia and Greece, then delivers a farewell address to the Ephesian elders in Miletus. He warns them of coming difficulties and commends them to God's grace while heading toward Jerusalem.
chapterSummaries.21: Despite warnings from the Holy Spirit, Paul continues to Jerusalem where he is arrested in the temple after being falsely accused of bringing Gentiles into restricted areas. Roman soldiers rescue him from an angry mob.
chapterSummaries.22: Paul addresses the Jerusalem crowd in Hebrew, recounting his conversion and calling to minister to the Gentiles. The crowd listens until he mentions the Gentiles, then erupts in anger demanding his death.
chapterSummaries.23: Paul appears before the Sanhedrin and cleverly divides the council by raising the issue of resurrection. After discovering a plot to kill Paul, Roman officials secretly transfer him to Caesarea for his protection.
chapterSummaries.24: Paul defends himself before Governor Felix against accusations brought by the high priest Ananias and lawyer Tertullus. Felix keeps Paul imprisoned for two years, occasionally summoning him to hear about faith in Christ.
chapterSummaries.25: The new governor Festus hears Paul's case and suggests he return to Jerusalem for trial. Paul exercises his right as a Roman citizen and appeals to Caesar, ensuring his journey to Rome.
